content.text: Once upon a time, there was a poor fisherman who lived with his wife in a tiny, tumbledown hut by the edge of the wild, stormy sea.
The hut was so small and shabby that it seemed ready to fall apart at any moment, and the fisherman and his wife had barely enough to eat.
Every day, the fisherman would go down to the shore, cast his net into the water, and wait patiently for a fish to bite.
But no matter how long he waited, he rarely caught more than a few small, scrawny fish—just enough to keep hunger from their door.
One evening, as the sun dipped low and painted the sky with streaks of gold and crimson, the fisherman cast his net into the sea as he always did.
He pulled and tugged, and when he finally hauled the net ashore, he found a single fish caught in its meshes.
But this was no ordinary fish—it was a great, gleaming flounder, shimmering like a rainbow in the fading light.
And to the fisherman’s astonishment, the flounder spoke to him in a voice as soft as the lapping waves.
“Good fisherman,” said the flounder, “I beg you, throw me back into the sea.
I am no common fish, but an enchanted prince.
If you set me free, I will grant you any wish your heart desires.”  The fisherman was amazed.
He had never heard of a talking fish before, let alone one that could grant wishes!
But he was a kind and humble man, and he shook his head.
“I do not need anything,” he said. “You may go free without any reward.
A life is worth more than gold.”  And with that, he gently lifted the flounder from the net and tossed it back into the sea.
The fish splashed its tail once, twice, and then vanished beneath the waves, leaving only a ripple behind.
When the fisherman returned home, he told his wife what had happened.
She listened with wide eyes, and when he finished, she clapped her hands together.
“Oh, you foolish man!” she cried. “Did you not ask for anything at all?
We live in a wretched hut, and our clothes are rags.

Go back at once and tell the flounder we want a snug little cottage—a proper house with a chimney and a garden!”  The fisherman did not like the idea of bothering the flounder again, but his wife was so insistent that he had no choice.
He trudged back to the shore, where the sea was now dark and restless, its waves crashing against the rocks.
He stood at the water’s edge and called out:  *“Flounder, flounder in the sea, Come now and listen unto me.
My wife, good Ilsebil, has sent me to beg a boon of thee.”*  At once, the flounder rose to the surface, its scales glinting in the moonlight.
“What does she want?” it asked.
“My wife says we cannot go on living in our old hut,” said the fisherman.
“She wishes for a snug little cottage with a chimney and a garden.”  “Go home,” said the flounder.

“She has it already.”  The fisherman hurried back to the place where his hut had stood—and there, in its place, was a charming little cottage with whitewashed walls, a red-tiled roof, and a garden bursting with flowers.
His wife stood in the doorway, beaming with delight. “Isn’t it wonderful?” she cried.
“Now we shall live like kings!”  For a time, the fisherman and his wife were content.
But soon, the wife began to grumble.
“This cottage is all very well,” she said, “but it is still too small.
I want a great stone castle, with towers and a drawbridge and servants to wait on me.
Go back to the flounder and tell him!”  The fisherman sighed.
“My dear, the flounder has already been so kind.
Are you sure we need more?”  But his wife would not be swayed. “Go at once!” she snapped.
So the fisherman returned to the shore, where the sea was now gray and choppy, its waves hissing like angry serpents.
He called out:  *“Flounder, flounder in the sea, Come now and listen unto me.
My wife, good Ilsebil, has sent me to beg a boon of thee.”*  The flounder appeared once more.
“What does she want now?” it asked. “She says the cottage is not enough,” said the fisherman.
“She wants a great stone castle with towers and a drawbridge and servants.”  “Go home,” said the flounder.
“She has it already.”  When the fisherman returned, he found a magnificent castle standing where the cottage had been.
Its walls were tall and strong, its towers reached high into the sky, and servants bustled about, bowing as he passed.
His wife stood on the grand balcony, dressed in fine silks, and she waved to him proudly.
“Now we are truly great!” she declared. But her happiness did not last.
The very next day, she summoned her husband and said, “This castle is splendid, but I am still not satisfied.
I want to be king—ruler of all the land!
Go to the flounder and tell him!”  The fisherman’s heart sank. “My dear, this is too much.
The flounder will grow angry if we keep asking for more.”  “Nonsense!” his wife scoffed.
“Do as I say!”  With a heavy heart, the fisherman returned to the shore.
The sea was now black and stormy, its waves crashing like thunder against the cliffs.
He called out:  *“Flounder, flounder in the sea, Come now and listen unto me.
My wife, good Ilsebil, has sent me to beg a boon of thee.”*  The flounder rose from the depths, its eyes dark and troubled.
“What does she want now?” it asked. “She wants to be king,” said the fisherman.
“Go home,” said the flounder.
“She is king already.”  When the fisherman returned, he found his wife seated upon a golden throne, wearing a crown of jewels.
The land stretched out before her, and her subjects bowed as she passed. But even this was not enough.
The next day, she called her husband to her and said, “Being king is well and good, but I want more.
I want to be emperor—the ruler of all the world!
Go to the flounder and tell him!”  The fisherman pleaded with her. “My dear, this is madness!
The flounder will not grant such a wish.
We must be content with what we have.”  But his wife would not listen. “Go!” she commanded.
So the fisherman returned to the shore, where the sea was now a raging tempest, its waves towering like mountains.
He called out:  *“Flounder, flounder in the sea, Come now and listen unto me.
My wife, good Ilsebil, has sent me to beg a boon of thee.”*  The flounder appeared, its voice weary.
“What does she want now?” it asked. “She wants to be emperor,” said the fisherman.
“Go home,” said the flounder.
“She is emperor already.”  When the fisherman returned, he found his wife seated upon a throne of gold and diamonds, with armies marching at her command and kings bowing before her.
But her ambition knew no bounds.
The very next day, she summoned her husband and said, “Being emperor is grand, but I want to be pope—the holiest of all!
Go to the flounder and tell him!”  The fisherman fell to his knees. “My dear, this is too much!
The flounder will not grant such a wish.
We must stop before it is too late!”  But his wife only sneered.
“Go at once!”  With tears in his eyes, the fisherman returned to the shore.
The sea was now a howling, furious storm, its waves crashing with the force of a thousand hammers.
He called out:  *“Flounder, flounder in the sea, Come now and listen unto me.
My wife, good Ilsebil, has sent me to beg a boon of thee.”*  The flounder rose from the depths, its voice like the rumble of distant thunder.
“What does she want now?” it asked. “She wants to be pope,” said the fisherman.
“Go home,” said the flounder.
“She is pope already.”  When the fisherman returned, he found his wife seated upon a throne of pure gold, dressed in the robes of the pope, with cardinals and bishops kneeling at her feet.
But even this was not enough.
The next day, she called her husband to her and said, “Being pope is powerful, but I want to be something greater still.
I want to be like God—to command the sun and the moon and the stars!
Go to the flounder and tell him!”  The fisherman wept. “My dear, this is the end!
The flounder will not grant such a wish.
We have asked for too much already!”  But his wife only laughed. “Go!” she cried.
With a heavy heart, the fisherman returned to the shore.
The sea was now a writhing, monstrous thing, its waves black as ink and its winds screaming like demons.
He called out:  *“Flounder, flounder in the sea, Come now and listen unto me.
My wife, good Ilsebil, has sent me to beg a boon of thee.”*  The flounder rose from the depths, its eyes burning like coals.
“What does she want now?” it growled. “She wants to be like God,” said the fisherman, his voice trembling.
The flounder did not answer at first.
The sea fell still, and the wind died away, leaving only an eerie silence.
Then, at last, the flounder spoke. “Go home,” it said.
“She sits once more in the old hut.”  And when the fisherman returned, he found his wife sitting in their tumbledown hut, just as they had lived before.
The castle, the throne, the crown—all were gone.
The sea raged outside, and the wind howled through the cracks in the walls.
The fisherman and his wife looked at each other, and for the first time in a long while, they were silent.
And so they lived out their days in their little hut by the sea, with no more wishes to make and no more dreams of grandeur.
And though they were poor, they were wiser than they had been before.
